issue.title: <frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?
<frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?
<frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?
<frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?
<frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?
<frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?
<frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?
<frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?

content.raw:
1) Yes, the intent is to support multiple frames per parent. I'll work on updating the  unittest.

2) Yes, a frame in model should be able to reference a frame in a child link. I'll tackle the unittest while work in part 1.

2.a) I agree that it's ambiguous. Historically, SDF has assumed that a `<pose>` is relative to it's parent SDF element. In your example, the  link's pose would be in the parent model frame. I'll update the documentation to say that a `<pose>` element with an unnamed `frame` attribute will use the parent element's frame.

4) Automatic frames are a good idea. Are you interested in taking a look at this, or should I?
content.html:
1) Yes, the intent is to support multiple frames per parent. I'll work on updating the unittest.

2) Yes, a frame in model should be able to reference a frame in a child link. I'll tackle the unittest while work in part 1.

2.a) I agree that it's ambiguous. Historically, SDF has assumed that a <pose> is relative to it's parent SDF element. In your example, the link's pose would be in the parent model frame. I'll update the documentation to say that a <pose> element with an unnamed frame attribute will use the parent element's frame.

4) Automatic frames are a good idea. Are you interested in taking a look at this, or should I?

issue.title: <frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?

content.raw:
Awesome, thank you!

For (4), I can take a whack at it. Can I ask what'd be best?
Perhaps a PR off of `master` that updates the spec, and afterwards I can mayhaps take your `pose_dom` branch and tinker with it there?
content.html:
Awesome, thank you!

For (4), I can take a whack at it. Can I ask what'd be best? Perhaps a PR off of master that updates the spec, and afterwards I can mayhaps take your pose_dom branch and tinker with it there?

issue.title: <frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?

content.raw:
From interpreting the current code and the above answers, I've got a couple more questions whenever you have time:

5) The elements that I see which have `<frames/>` listed as a child composite element are list below; however, the only place I saw this implemented seemed to be `link`. Is that a follow-up item in your current prototype branch?
```
$ grep -rnI -l 'filename="frame\.sdf"' sdf/1.6 | sort
sdf/1.6/actor.sdf
sdf/1.6/audio_source.sdf
sdf/1.6/camera.sdf
sdf/1.6/collision.sdf
sdf/1.6/gui.sdf
sdf/1.6/inertial.sdf
sdf/1.6/joint.sdf
sdf/1.6/light.sdf
sdf/1.6/light_state.sdf
sdf/1.6/link.sdf
sdf/1.6/link_state.sdf
sdf/1.6/model.sdf
sdf/1.6/model_state.sdf
sdf/1.6/population.sdf
sdf/1.6/projector.sdf
sdf/1.6/sensor.sdf
sdf/1.6/visual.sdf
```

6) A frame added to any of these elements should be accessible by its parent; does this propagation stop at the
`<model/>` level (e.g. a frame inside of `<model/>` should not refer to a frame outside of it, even if it's defined inline or a nested model)? e.g. the following is illegal:

```xml
<sdf version="1.6">
  <world name="default">
    <model name="box">
      <frame name="box_frame">
        <pose>...</pose>
      </frame>
      <model name="box_child">
        <frame name="box_child_frame_good">...</frame>
        <frame name="box_child_frame">
          <!-- BAD (b): Crossing model boundary, even if it's nested -> parent -->
          <pose frame="box_frame">...</pose>
        </frame>
      </model>
      <frame name="box_frame_attached_to_child">
        <!-- BAD (c): Crossing model boundary, even if it's parent -> nested -->
        <pose frame="box_child_frame_good">...</frame>
      </frame>
    </model>
    <model name="box_2">
      <frame name="box_frame_2">
       <!-- BAD (a): Crossing model boundary -->
        <pose frame="box_frame">...</pose>
      </frame>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>
```

7) The best way to avoid name collision among automatic frames would be to ensure that all non-frame elements have unique names; does SDF already require that all elements have unique names (aside from frames)? (e.g. you can have `/model//link[@name="my_link"]` and implicitly `/model//frame[@name="my_link"]`, but not `/model//camera[@name="my_link"]`?)

I'll be keeping tabs on your branch to see how things progress - thanks again!
content.html:
From interpreting the current code and the above answers, I've got a couple more questions whenever you have time:

5) The elements that I see which have <frames/> listed as a child composite element are list below; however, the only place I saw this implemented seemed to be link. Is that a follow-up item in your current prototype branch?

$ grep -rnI -l 'filename="frame\.sdf"' sdf/1.6 | sort
sdf/1.6/actor.sdf
sdf/1.6/audio_source.sdf
sdf/1.6/camera.sdf
sdf/1.6/collision.sdf
sdf/1.6/gui.sdf
sdf/1.6/inertial.sdf
sdf/1.6/joint.sdf
sdf/1.6/light.sdf
sdf/1.6/light_state.sdf
sdf/1.6/link.sdf
sdf/1.6/link_state.sdf
sdf/1.6/model.sdf
sdf/1.6/model_state.sdf
sdf/1.6/population.sdf
sdf/1.6/projector.sdf
sdf/1.6/sensor.sdf
sdf/1.6/visual.sdf

6) A frame added to any of these elements should be accessible by its parent; does this propagation stop at the <model/> level (e.g. a frame inside of <model/> should not refer to a frame outside of it, even if it's defined inline or a nested model)? e.g. the following is illegal:

<sdf version="1.6">
  <world name="default">
    <model name="box">
      <frame name="box_frame">
        <pose>...</pose>
      </frame>
      <model name="box_child">
        <frame name="box_child_frame_good">...</frame>
        <frame name="box_child_frame">
          <!-- BAD (b): Crossing model boundary, even if it's nested -> parent -->
          <pose frame="box_frame">...</pose>
        </frame>
      </model>
      <frame name="box_frame_attached_to_child">
        <!-- BAD (c): Crossing model boundary, even if it's parent -> nested -->
        <pose frame="box_child_frame_good">...</frame>
      </frame>
    </model>
    <model name="box_2">
      <frame name="box_frame_2">
       <!-- BAD (a): Crossing model boundary -->
        <pose frame="box_frame">...</pose>
      </frame>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>

7) The best way to avoid name collision among automatic frames would be to ensure that all non-frame elements have unique names; does SDF already require that all elements have unique names (aside from frames)? (e.g. you can have /model//link[@name="my_link"] and implicitly /model//frame[@name="my_link"], but not /model//camera[@name="my_link"]?)

I'll be keeping tabs on your branch to see how things progress - thanks again!

issue.title: <frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?

content.raw:
5) Link is a prototype. I'll be adding `frames` to each element that needs frame information. This might span a few pull requests.

6) I'm leaning toward stopping frame propagation at the model level. Do you want to see cross-model frame propagation?

7) Good point. I'll have to update the code to prevent duplicate names for all sibling elements.
content.html:
5) Link is a prototype. I'll be adding frames to each element that needs frame information. This might span a few pull requests.

6) I'm leaning toward stopping frame propagation at the model level. Do you want to see cross-model frame propagation?

7) Good point. I'll have to update the code to prevent duplicate names for all sibling elements.

issue.title: <frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?

content.raw:
5) Makes sense!

6) Nope, not looking for cross-model propagation, definitely most satisfied with a model boundary. (Keeps things nice and encapsulated.)

7) Thanks!

Now, uh, adding one more question that came up:

8) Can you refer the model's frame explicitly? e.g.
```xml
<model name="my_model">
   <frame name="a">
     <!-- Same as `<pose>...</pose>`? -->
     <pose frame="my_model">...</pose>
   </frame>
</model>
```
If so, how would you handle the rename of a `model`  via an `//include/name` element?

In Drake, we just merged initial support for the `<frame/>` tag [[ref](https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/pull/9352)]; however, I'm unsure if I should permit users to access the model's frame in an SDF.

If users should be able to access it, then should they only be able to access it via the model-specified name, not the include-override name?
If that's the case, can I ask if it's possible to access the original name via `sdf::Model`?

(All in all, it looks like the easiest solution for now might be to say you can't refer to a model's frame explicitly inside SDF, and if a user wants the model frame, they should specify a `//frame/pose` element without `@frame`?)
content.html:
5) Makes sense!

6) Nope, not looking for cross-model propagation, definitely most satisfied with a model boundary. (Keeps things nice and encapsulated.)

7) Thanks!

Now, uh, adding one more question that came up:

8) Can you refer the model's frame explicitly? e.g.

<model name="my_model">
   <frame name="a">
     <!-- Same as `<pose>...</pose>`? -->
     <pose frame="my_model">...</pose>
   </frame>
</model>

If so, how would you handle the rename of a model via an //include/name element?

In Drake, we just merged initial support for the <frame/> tag [ref]; however, I'm unsure if I should permit users to access the model's frame in an SDF.

If users should be able to access it, then should they only be able to access it via the model-specified name, not the include-override name? If that's the case, can I ask if it's possible to access the original name via sdf::Model?

(All in all, it looks like the easiest solution for now might be to say you can't refer to a model's frame explicitly inside SDF, and if a user wants the model frame, they should specify a //frame/pose element without @frame?)

issue.title: <frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?

content.raw: 9) Can frames be specified against `"world"` as well?
content.html: 9) Can frames be specified against "world" as well?

issue.title: <frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?

content.raw:
8) Yes, you should be able to reference the model's frame explicitly. I'll have to think on how to address the renaming issue.

9) A model's pose, by default, is in the `<world>` frame. Here is a potential problem:

```
<world>
  <model>
    <pose frame="a_link">...</pose>
    <link name="a_link">
    </link>
  </model>
</world>
```

I don't think there is value in allowing links, visuals, collisions to specify a pose in the world frame. Thoughts on this?

So, we could mandate that a model's pose must be in the world frame, and nothing else can be in the world frame. One exception would be a nested model, which could have a pose in any frame local the parent model.
content.html:
8) Yes, you should be able to reference the model's frame explicitly. I'll have to think on how to address the renaming issue.

9) A model's pose, by default, is in the <world> frame. Here is a potential problem:

<world>
  <model>
    <pose frame="a_link">...</pose>
    <link name="a_link">
    </link>
  </model>
</world>

I don't think there is value in allowing links, visuals, collisions to specify a pose in the world frame. Thoughts on this?

So, we could mandate that a model's pose must be in the world frame, and nothing else can be in the world frame. One exception would be a nested model, which could have a pose in any frame local the parent model.

issue.title: <frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?

content.raw:
8) Looking forward to it!

9) Per your above example, I definitely agree that *model* poses should not be able to have a frame specified (or it should only be `world`), and there should be no interdependency between the model frame and its child elements frames.

I do find value in being able to specify the `world` frame explicitly in `//model//frame` elements; if we want the parent frame to be the model frame, then we can do that on purpose.

I'm not sure I see the harm in preventing a model and its children from specifying `world` explicitly. At present, you can define joints that weld items to the `world`, so I would see it as kind of similar? Plus, enforcing this may make the parsing the frames a tad more complex than it may already be?
content.html:
8) Looking forward to it!

9) Per your above example, I definitely agree that model poses should not be able to have a frame specified (or it should only be world), and there should be no interdependency between the model frame and its child elements frames.

I do find value in being able to specify the world frame explicitly in //model//frame elements; if we want the parent frame to be the model frame, then we can do that on purpose.

I'm not sure I see the harm in preventing a model and its children from specifying world explicitly. At present, you can define joints that weld items to the world, so I would see it as kind of similar? Plus, enforcing this may make the parsing the frames a tad more complex than it may already be?

issue.title: <frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?

content.raw: I've spent some time reviewing pull request #468 (branch `pose_dom`) and recently made pull request #505 targeted against `pose_dom` to fix some errors in its implementation but largely following its current design. I'll answer some of your questions 1-9 based on my understanding of the code in these two pull request and discuss where they are currently lacking. I'll address each question in a separate comment.
content.html: I've spent some time reviewing pull request #468 (branch pose_dom) and recently made pull request #505 targeted against pose_dom to fix some errors in its implementation but largely following its current design. I'll answer some of your questions 1-9 based on my understanding of the code in these two pull request and discuss where they are currently lacking. I'll address each question in a separate comment.

issue.title: <frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?

content.raw: Question 1: the `pose_dom` branch is currently only parsing `<frame/>` elements under the `<model/>` tag, but I expect it would be added to the other DOM classes as well. The [link_chain.sdf](#!/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/468/pose-dom/diff#chg-test/sdf/link_chain.sdf) example file has multiple `<frame/>` elements, which are tested in the [LinkChain test](#!/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/468/pose-dom/diff#Ltest/integration/link_dom.ccT534) in `test/integration/link_dom.cc`. So, yes, multiple frame tags are supported.
content.html: Question 1: the pose_dom branch is currently only parsing <frame/> elements under the <model/> tag, but I expect it would be added to the other DOM classes as well. The link_chain.sdf example file has multiple <frame/> elements, which are tested in the LinkChain test in test/integration/link_dom.cc. So, yes, multiple frame tags are supported.

issue.title: <frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?

content.raw:
Question 2: Currently there is no namespacing for frame names in the `pose_dom` graph, so any frame can be referenced from anywhere else, but I expect that we will change that, since we currently allow collision / visual "cousins" to have the same name (many existing sdf models have multiple links with only 1 collision / visual that are all named "collision" / "visual").

The specific example you gave currently won't pass a unit test because the `pose_dom` branch doesn't yet parse `<frame/>` tags under links, only under models. I expect this will change also.
content.html:
Question 2: Currently there is no namespacing for frame names in the pose_dom graph, so any frame can be referenced from anywhere else, but I expect that we will change that, since we currently allow collision / visual "cousins" to have the same name (many existing sdf models have multiple links with only 1 collision / visual that are all named "collision" / "visual").

The specific example you gave currently won't pass a unit test because the pose_dom branch doesn't yet parse <frame/> tags under links, only under models. I expect this will change also.

issue.title: <frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?

content.raw:
Question 2.a: If you don't specify the `frame` attribute for the `<pose>` element, it currently takes as a default value the conventions from earlier version of sdformat, which is usually the frame of the parent element, except in the case of a `<joint><pose>`, which will take the name of the child link.

There are tests that confirm this behavior in pull request #468 using the [double_pendulum.sdf](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/21d2cbe52bbd104f24a50b0037e5b3da5657c644/test/sdf/double_pendulum.sdf?fileviewer=file-view-default) example:

* default joint pose frame test added to `test/integration/joint_dom.cc` in 3f04e7c35e1b
* default link pose frame, which is model name, is tested in [test/integration/link_dom.cc](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/3f04e7c35e1b11cd43c9719a8fba7077fa11b611/test/integration/link_dom.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#link_dom.cc-285:323)
* default collision pose frame, which is model name, is tested in [test/integration/collision_dom.cc](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/3f04e7c35e1b11cd43c9719a8fba7077fa11b611/test/integration/collision_dom.cc?at=pose_dom&fileviewer=file-view-default#collision_dom.cc-104:110)
content.html:
Question 2.a: If you don't specify the frame attribute for the <pose> element, it currently takes as a default value the conventions from earlier version of sdformat, which is usually the frame of the parent element, except in the case of a <joint><pose>, which will take the name of the child link.

There are tests that confirm this behavior in pull request #468 using the double_pendulum.sdf example:

  • default joint pose frame test added to test/integration/joint_dom.cc in 3f04e7c35e1b
  • default link pose frame, which is model name, is tested in test/integration/link_dom.cc
  • default collision pose frame, which is model name, is tested in test/integration/collision_dom.cc

issue.title: <frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?

content.raw: Question 3: The code in pull request #468 currently adds names of models, links, joints, collisions, and visuals to the frame graph, so they can be referenced by name without adding explicit `<frame>` sub-elements.
content.html: Question 3: The code in pull request #468 currently adds names of models, links, joints, collisions, and visuals to the frame graph, so they can be referenced by name without adding explicit <frame> sub-elements.

issue.title: <frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?

content.raw: Question 4 seems to be an alias of question 3.
content.html: Question 4 seems to be an alias of question 3.

issue.title: <frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?

content.raw: Question 5: `<frame>` elements are in the spec for many elements, as you noted, but in pull request #468, they are only parsed as sub-elements of `<model>`. This will be fixed eventually.
content.html: Question 5: <frame> elements are in the spec for many elements, as you noted, but in pull request #468, they are only parsed as sub-elements of <model>. This will be fixed eventually.

issue.title: <frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?

content.raw: Question 6: I need to think about this more.
content.html: Question 6: I need to think about this more.

issue.title: <frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?

content.raw:
Question 7: Currently the code in pull request #468 doesn't allow sibling tags of the same type to have the same name. For example, the following two example files return an error when calling `Model::Load`:

* [model_duplicate_links.sdf](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/3f04e7c35e1b11cd43c9719a8fba7077fa11b611/test/sdf/model_duplicate_links.sdf?at=pose_dom&fileviewer=file-view-default) has two sibling links named `link`
* [model_duplicate_joints.sdf](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/3f04e7c35e1b11cd43c9719a8fba7077fa11b611/test/sdf/model_duplicate_joints.sdf?at=pose_dom&fileviewer=file-view-default) has two sibling joints named `joint`

It is possible to load sibling elements of different types with the same name, though the pose resolution is currently broken (see [model_link_joint_same_name.sdf](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/3f04e7c35e1b11cd43c9719a8fba7077fa11b611/test/sdf/model_link_joint_same_name.sdf?at=pose_dom&fileviewer=file-view-default) and its [corresponding test](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/3f04e7c35e1b11cd43c9719a8fba7077fa11b611/test/integration/model_dom.cc?at=pose_dom&fileviewer=file-view-default#model_dom.cc-144:184)).
content.html:
Question 7: Currently the code in pull request #468 doesn't allow sibling tags of the same type to have the same name. For example, the following two example files return an error when calling Model::Load:

  • model_duplicate_links.sdf has two sibling links named link
  • model_duplicate_joints.sdf has two sibling joints named joint

It is possible to load sibling elements of different types with the same name, though the pose resolution is currently broken (see model_link_joint_same_name.sdf and its corresponding test).

issue.title: <frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?

content.raw: Question 8: Without really getting into the `<include>` tag, currently in pull request #468 you can refer to the model frame by the model's current name, not the original name of the model given in a `uri://` string.
content.html: Question 8: Without really getting into the <include> tag, currently in pull request #468 you can refer to the model frame by the model's current name, not the original name of the model given in a uri:// string.

issue.title: <frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?

content.raw:
> Question 3: The code in pull request #468 currently adds names of models, links, joints, collisions, and visuals to [...]

Is this the short-term desired functionality? Or is there time still to simplify this and only create implicit frames for links + joints, and ignore models, collisions, and visuals for now?
content.html:
Question 3: The code in pull request #468 currently adds names of models, links, joints, collisions, and visuals to [...]

Is this the short-term desired functionality? Or is there time still to simplify this and only create implicit frames for links + joints, and ignore models, collisions, and visuals for now?

issue.title: <frame/>: Support multiple frames in a single parent? Intended scope of frames? Use link names as frames?
